pros: Personalized attention from the managers that care about your needs and challenged you to achieve your own goals within the roles.
cons: Did not experience any cons.

pros: You can possibly be hired by client permanently
cons: It was a Contract position

pros: Amazing organization and services provided, you were able to say your work was positively impacting local women and their families.
cons:
Not great for younger staff, a feeling that your work was not as valued and/or trusted. Younger staff members are often seen as too green, or not knowledgable in their field regardless of previous experiences. 

There was a feeling of competition instead of collaboration, especially between seasoned staff and newcomers.

Not much room for internal advancement, always looking outside the company for strengths that already existed (or could be nurtured/trained) within. 

Dress code is too strict, and if attire isn't exactly right (deemed too low-cut, not enough sleeve, too short etc) the avenue for addressing the violation was often shame tactics and un-kind commentary.

review_title: Pretty in Pink on the outside - Toxicity abounds on the inside
pros: helping women access mammograms with special focus on the uninsured and low-income; flexibility with schedules; approachable senior management (COO, CFO, Development and Centers Directors); restaurants nearby and quick access to freeway; good equipment/software; open-toe shoes allowed (although CEO preferred panty hose!!!).  Dr. Melilo well-known and respected.  Everyone loves their care with her and the other doctors.
cons: low pay, low moral.  expensive health care benefits; overpaid CEO points finger (or taps it on table) and uses shaming language to intimidate or silence most, putting everyone on edge.  sleeveless tops not allowed.  new/ creative ideas not welcomed.  management would benefit from youth and diversity in order to grow with the times and reach more women.  witnessed fundraising $$ that did not get back into program helping uninsured women get mammograms.

pros: The mission is great and people are truly helped.
cons: Employees are not treated well.  The best word to use is unkind.  You would think with a company full of women that there would b true caring.  There is not.  The workload keeps increasing without adding staff making it hard to get everything done daily.  Now they are opening Saturday's making staff cover that also.

pros: The team at The Rose lives their values and are committed to saving the lives of women. The women who work there truly care about the work they do and they go above and beyond to create an inviting environment. I have worked with several nonprofits through the years and few demonstrate this high level of professionalism, team building and compassion.
cons: Like most nonprofits, resources are spread thin so everyone is busy a lot. But they do their best and that's all you can hope for.

pros: Flexibility & work life balance. I've never heard "we've always done it that way". Large selection in benefit choices for a non-profit.  People care about each other. Great non-profit rating and $ goes to services
cons: Vacation/sick time is average with most companies, but not as great as other non-profits

pros:
Great place to work. Constantly making a difference in our local community. Lots of opportunities to help many women in Texas - not only the insured but the uninsured.

The leadership is strong and always visible.
cons: Would love to see certain departments have more staff members due to the high demand at times.

pros: As a Development intern, I have been treated as an equal and my opinions matter. I have been exposed to a wide range of opportunities such as production, marketing collateral, etc...
cons: No cons to report at this time.

pros: There are women at the org that really care.   Unfortunately, they are not the top leaders who control how things run.
cons: The pay is low, the benefits are terrible, the consideration for the staff to have a work life balance does not exist.

pros: Vision driven organization that has been fighting for women's health care for 30 years
cons: Passionate pursuit of helping others can be tiring

pros:
Compassion, people who love their job and care about others.
Good benefits, open door policy.
cons: Non-profit so a little less pay scale than similar positions
